title: Introduction to kubectl
content: kubectl is the **command-line tool** used to interact with Kubernetes clusters. It allows you to deploy applications, inspect and manage cluster resources, and view logs.

title: kubectl Purpose
content:
- Communicate with the Kubernetes API Server
- Manage and inspect resources like pods, services, deployments
- Apply configurations from YAML files
- Debug and monitor your Kubernetes environment

content.Description: List all pods in the current namespace
List all nodes in the cluster
Show detailed info about a specific pod
Create or update resources from a YAML file

title: kubectl with YAML Files
content:
kubectl can apply, delete, or replace Kubernetes resources using YAML configuration files.

Example:
```
kubectl apply -f deployment.yaml
```

title: kubectl Configuration
content:
- Configuration is stored in the **kubeconfig** file
- Default path: `~/.kube/config`
- It contains cluster info, user credentials, and context settings

title: Setting Context with kubectl
content:
```
kubectl config use-context <context-name>
```  
Use this command to switch between different Kubernetes clusters.

title: kubectl Tips for Beginners
content:
- Use `kubectl get all` to see all resources
- Use `kubectl explain <resource>` to understand resource structure
- Combine with `--namespace` to target specific namespaces

title: Conclusion
content: kubectl is a **powerful tool** to control and manage Kubernetes clusters. Mastering it is essential for any Kubernetes developer or administrator.
